title: Mackenzie District Council agrees to compensate man over dog shooting
text:
Mackenzie District Council agrees to compensate man over dog shooting DAISY HUDSON Last updated 18:28, February 3 2017 MYTCHALL BRANSGROVE/FAIRFAX NZ 
Arthur Paul Welsh, pictured with his new dog which he got to replace the one shot by the Mackenzie District Council. 
The Mackenzie District Council will compensate a Fairlie man after admitting it made an error by shooting his dog. 
The amount of compensation the council will pay Arthur Welsh will remain confidential after the two parties reached a settlement on Friday. 
It has been nearly two years since Welsh's dog Jake was shot by a council staff member following a noise complaint in Fairlie. 
The incident has prompted a review of council procedures, and an apology to Welsh. 
Welsh claimed a dog control officer knocked on his door in June 2015 and told him he was there to take his dog because of a noise complaint from then-mayor Claire Barlow, who lived across the street. 
READ MORE: Court looms over dog shooting 
"Then I rung him up the next day and got through to him and he said Jake had been shot last night." 
Welsh said he received no written notice that Jake might be taken, no phone call beforehand, and he had not given the approval to destroy him. 
At the time, Barlow said she had informed council staff about a neighbour's concerns and that was the end of her involvement. 
"I was walking to work around the time of the big snowstorm and one of my neighbours approached me. Ad Feedback 
"She said she did not know what to do because his dog had been crying all night in the cold," Barlow said. 
"She had taken a blanket to its kennel and she was worried the dog would freeze in the nights ahead." 
She was simply passing on a message, she said. 
"I don't agree with the way we have followed the process in this instance - we should have had a surrender form signed - and we need to learn a lesson from that." 
Welsh's lawyer, Jay Lovely, released a statement on behalf of Welsh and the council on Friday. 
It includes an acknowledgment from the council that it made a mistake in shooting Jake. 
"The council acknowledges that an error was made when Mr Welsh's dog Jake was destroyed. 
"A number of factors contributed to that error. The error is regretted. It also caused distress to Mr Welsh." 
No one person was at fault, according to the statement. 
"The council has reviewed its procedures and would like to commit to giving people as much time as is practical in the decision as to whether a dog will be destroyed. 
"Council and its employees take its obligations and duties seriously, and want to perform those to the highest standard." 
The council had apologised to Welsh, and would pay him an agreed amount in compensation. 
The settlement follows a year in which the council's legal costs reached $375,000. 
Of the money spent by the council on legal fees in 2016, $160,000 was a result of district plan changes and plan reviews. 
Land sales and leases resulted in a $134,000 bill, while other regulatory matters cost the council $21,000. 
The remaining $60,000 was a result of "other legal matters". - Stuff
